seg.seg: ... I speak about the manifestation of the coming of great merit. What is the problem?
... having materialized by ..., blissfulness [and] patience, the jewel of a Community ...
... the noble Community which proﬁts from a monk’s leaving (the house), ... all virtues
... receiver of gifts ... of the (world?). Therefore, o Ānanda, whoever pays homage to the Community, (also) to the Buddha ...
... || Then, queen Gautamī thinks: What then are these fourteen Pudgalika (gifts)?
... a gift given to the Buddha-god is called a Pudgalika gift. A gift given to a Pratyekabuddha (is called) a Pudgalika (gift);
... to (an Anāgāmin); to someone striving for the status of Anāgāmin; to a Sakṛdāgāmin; to (someone striving for the) status of Sakṛdāgāmin; ...
... to someone striving for (the status of Srotaāpanna); to the ... ascetic unconcerned with desire; to someone who has observed (the proper behavior); ...
... a gift given to living beings is called a Pudgalika gift. || Then, ... to the king Śuddhodana ...
... said by the Buddha-god the teacher (to be) like the sky without measure [and] without end. The Pudgalika (gift) ... to beings
The Buddha-god the teacher, having understood the thought of the Śākyas, says: To one born in the existence of the animals
... in (a hundred) births they are without privation from all possessions. || To one who has not (observed) all ten good things,
... by giving a gift ..., (they are) without privation from all possessions in a thousand births.
... by giving ..., (they are) without (privation) from all possessions in hundred thousand births.
... having made a gift to someone who has driven away (the Kleśas), (they are without privation from) all (possessions) in a trillion births.
... by giving a gift to someone who is striving ..., in births without measure [and] without number ... the (fruit) ...

This fragment contains part of the third act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami III, 8b20-9b20. See also 196-7.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 186.
In the Uyghur text, the end of the verso of the 8th leaf is partly destroyed, with complete loss of about 5 lines.
Cf. MaitrHami 3, 8 b24.
The lines 3-5 contain remnants of a stanza of the type 4 x 25 (5/5/8/7).
TA pudgalik is a borrowing of the Buddhist term Skt. pudgalika-, Pali puggalika- ‘particular, individual’.
The 1st kind of Pudgalika gift, cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 a1-3; at the end of this line, the 2nd kind, cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 a3-4.
The 5th. 6th and 7th kind, cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 a7-8, a8-10 and a11-12 respectively.
The 8th kind, cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 a13-14.
The 10th and 11th kind, cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 a16 and the mutilated text in MaitrHami 3, 9 a16-18 respectively.
The 12th kind, cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 a19-20.

The 14th kind, cf. the mutilated text in MaitrHami 3, 9 a22ff. The end of the recto of the 9th leaf of the Uyghur text is lost, and the lacuna covers about ﬁve lines. The Tocharian text reports the thoughts of the Śākya noblemen, beginning with the king Śuddhodana.
Cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 b2ff.
Cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 b7ff.
Cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 b9-10.
Cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 b13.
TA kor is used to multiply śäk tmānäntu, hence the translation ‘a trillion’, compare MaitrHami 3, 9 b17.
Cf. MaitrHami 3, 9 b21.
